The Truth in Lending Act applies to loans made to: 

A. Businesses
B. Consumers
C. Nonprofit organizations
D. Government agencies

The Truth in Lending Act (TILA) applies to loans made to consumers. The correct answer is B: Consumers.

TILA is a federal law that was enacted to protect consumers from deceptive lending practices by requiring lenders to disclose certain information about the terms and conditions of their loans. The law applies to a wide range of consumer credit transactions, including mortgages, home equity loans, credit cards, and other types of consumer loans.

TILA requires lenders to provide borrowers with clear and concise information about the terms and conditions of their loans, including the annual percentage rate (APR), the total finance charge, and the total amount financed. This information must be disclosed in writing and must be presented in a clear and conspicuous manner so that borrowers can make informed decisions about whether to take out a loan.

TILA applies to loans made to individuals, but it does not apply to loans made to businesses, nonprofit organizations, or government agencies. These types of loans are typically governed by different laws and regulations.

Which is a closed-end loan? 

A. Adjustable-rate mortgage
B. Home equity line of credit
C. Credit card
D. Debit card

A closed-end loan is a type of loan that involves a single lump-sum borrowing, with a fixed repayment schedule and a fixed interest rate. Examples of closed-end loans include mortgages, car loans, and personal loans.

The correct answer is A: Adjustable-rate mortgage. An adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM) is a type of closed-end loan that allows the lender to adjust the interest rate on the loan periodically based on market conditions. The borrower is required to repay the loan in fixed installments over the life of the loan.

Other examples of closed-end loans include fixed-rate mortgages, car loans, and personal loans. These types of loans typically involve a single borrowing and have a fixed repayment schedule and interest rate.

On the other hand, open-end loans are loans that allow the borrower to borrow and repay funds repeatedly up to a certain credit limit. Examples of open-end loans include credit card accounts and home equity lines of credit (HELOCs). Credit cards and HELOCs are not closed-end loans, as the borrower is able to borrow and repay funds repeatedly within a certain credit limit. Debit cards are not loans and are not covered by TILA.

If your institution solicits customers to open credit card accounts, it must: 

A. Answer all questions in writing within 30 days
B. Determine the customer's credit rating
C. Explain all terms of the card
D. Require the customer to authorize the solicitation

If your institution solicits customers to open credit card accounts, it must explain all terms of the card. This means that the correct answer is C: Explain all terms of the card.

Under the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), credit card issuers are required to clearly and conspicuously disclose the terms and conditions of their credit card accounts to consumers. This includes information such as the annual percentage rate (APR), fees, and any other terms and conditions that may apply to the account.

TILA requires credit card issuers to provide this information in writing and to present it in a clear and conspicuous manner so that consumers can make informed decisions about whether to open a credit card account.

TILA does not require credit card issuers to answer all questions in writing within 30 days, determine the customer's credit rating, or require the customer to authorize the solicitation. These requirements may be imposed by other laws or regulations.

Prepaid finance charges are: (Select all that apply.)

(The correct answers are A & D.)

A. Also known as the APR fees
B. In addition to the disclosed finance charge
C. Paid by the borrower after loan closing
D. Loan origination fees

Prepaid finance charges are loan origination fees. This means that the correct answer is D: Loan origination fees.

Prepaid finance charges are fees that are paid in advance by the borrower at the time the loan is originated. These fees are typically paid in connection with a mortgage loan and may include loan origination fees, points, and other fees associated with the loan.

Prepaid finance charges are also known as the APR fees. This means that the correct answer is A: Also known as the APR fees.

Prepaid finance charges are in addition to the disclosed finance charge. This means that the correct answer is B: In addition to the disclosed finance charge.

Prepaid finance charges are paid by the borrower at the time the loan is originated, not after loan closing. This means that the correct answer is C: Paid by the borrower after loan closing is incorrect.

For loans secured by a dwelling, if the APR may increase during the life of the loan, your institution must: 

A. Allow the applicant to convert to a fixed rate at any time
B. Disclose the maximum rate that may be imposed during the loan term
C. Notify the applicant every time the APR changes
D. Terminate the plan and demand repayment of the outstanding balance

For loans secured by a dwelling, if the annual percentage rate (APR) may increase during the life of the loan, your institution must disclose the maximum rate that may be imposed during the loan term. This means that the correct answer is B: Disclose the maximum rate that may be imposed during the loan term.

Under the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), lenders are required to clearly and conspicuously disclose the terms and conditions of loans secured by a dwelling, including information about the APR. If the APR may increase during the life of the loan, the lender must disclose the maximum rate that may be imposed and any conditions under which the rate may increase.

TILA does not require lenders to allow the applicant to convert to a fixed rate at any time, notify the applicant every time the APR changes, or terminate the plan and demand repayment of the outstanding balance. These requirements may be imposed by other laws or regulations.

The Truth in Lending Act requires that all of these be disclosed, EXCEPT: 

(The correct answer is C.)

A. Finance charges
B. Payment schedule
C. Total maximum late fees that can be assessed
D. Total of payments

The Truth in Lending Act (TILA) requires lenders to disclose all of the following: finance charges, payment schedule, and the total of payments. The correct answer is C: Total maximum late fees that can be assessed.

TILA is a federal law that was enacted to protect consumers from deceptive lending practices by requiring lenders to disclose certain information about the terms and conditions of their loans. TILA applies to a wide range of consumer credit transactions, including mortgages, home equity loans, credit cards, and other types of consumer loans.

TILA requires lenders to disclose information about the finance charges associated with a loan, including the annual percentage rate (APR) and any fees that may be charged. TILA also requires lenders to disclose the payment schedule, including the amount of each payment, the number of payments, and the due dates of the payments. In addition, TILA requires lenders to disclose the total of payments, which is the total amount that the borrower will pay over the life of the loan.

However, TILA does not require lenders to disclose the total maximum late fees that can be assessed. This information may be disclosed in the loan agreement or other documents provided to the borrower.

The Truth in Lending Act ensures that: 

A. All loans are processed fairly
B. The financial institutions comply with Regulation Z
C. The APR is higher than the interest rate
D. Loan terms are disclosed in a meaningful way

The Truth in Lending Act (TILA) ensures that loan terms are disclosed in a meaningful way. This means that the correct answer is D: Loan terms are disclosed in a meaningful way.
